__data__.text:
- Smithfield market in London was the main cattle market for centuries but became overcrowded and a public health nuisance due to increased trade volume and lack of refrigeration.
- In 1855, Parliament moved London's livestock market to a site in Islington called the Metropolitan Cattle Market.
- The new market was in Copenhagen Fields, Islington, and was built to accommodate the growing population and increasing demand for meat.
- The British farming industry could not satisfy the demand, so the Conservative government of Sir Robert Peel allowed all foreign cattle to be imported duty-free in 1842-6.
- By railway, the Metropolitan Cattle Market received livestock from most parts of Great Britain, Ireland, and the Continent.
- John Gamgee, a veterinary scientist, warned that free trade in animals was dangerous as it would import diseases, but his warnings were ignored.
- Cattle came from as far away as the plains of Hungary and Russia, which had never been free from cattle plague (rinderpest), an infectious disease highly mortal to immunologically naïve cattle.
- The cattle plague epidemic of 1865-7 was the most dramatic event in 19th century agricultural history, leading to the establishment of a second, quarantine market.
- The new market was to be known as the Foreign Cattle Market, and it was appreciated that not only rinderpest, but pleuro-pneumonia and foot-and-mouth disease were contagious threats.
- The Privy Council was authorized to "schedule" countries that were not disease-free, meaning animals from those countries must be landed at the new market and nowhere else.
- The new market was to operate under quarantine conditions, and no animal was to leave it alive.
- The new market was built on the Thames's south bank, on a 22-acre (8.9 ha) site of the defunct royal dockyard at Deptford.
- The site was chosen because it had a river frontage of 1,012 feet (308 m) and was situated on a bend in the Thames, at the bottom of Limehouse Reach.
- Three large, immensely strong, timber piers were constructed for disembarking cattle,

- The defunct royal dockyard at Deptford was chosen as the site for a new cattle market.
- The site was 22 acres (later expanded to 30 acres) with a river frontage of 1,012 feet, and had three large timber piers for disembarking cattle.
- Sir Horace Jones, architect of Smithfield Market and Tower Bridge, took a minimalist approach and adapted existing dockyard buildings for the new market.
- The market had a tidal basin surrounded by three ship-building sheds, which were converted into a pentagonal horseshoe-shaped lairage building with open sides facing the river and landing piers.
- The lairage building could accommodate 5,000 cattle and 14,000 sheep (later enlarged to 8,500 cattle and 20,000 sheep).
- Admiralty storehouses were converted into abattoirs with 70 slaughterhouses.
- The market opened for business in January 1872 and most cattle and sheep were slaughtered at Deptford by 1880.
- The market was surrounded by a high boundary wall and had services such as bank branches, a postal telegraph office, and the Peter the Great pub.
- Trading was by private bargain, and in live animals only. Exporters consigned cattle, sheep, and pigs to salesmen who worked on commission.
- Market days were Mondays and Thursdays, but animals could be sold on other days.
- Weighbridges were seldom used; cattle weights were guesstimated.
- Buyers were wholesale (and sometimes retail) butchers who had access to slaughterhouse space on the premises.
- Slaughtermen, paid by results, killed and butchered purchases for buyers within the 10 days required by law.
- By the end of 1887, some 9.4 million animals had been landed at Deptford.
- The volume of trade fluctuated, but by about 1890, more foreign cattle were sent to Deptford than British cattle to Islington.
- By 1907, 78% of London's live cattle trade went to Deptford.
- The largest number of cattle ever landed in

- Slaughtermen killed and butchered animals for buyers within 10 days required by law
- By end of 1887, 9.4 million animals had been landed at Deptford
- Trade fluctuated, but by 1890, more foreign cattle sent to Deptford than British to Islington
- By 1907, 78% of London's live cattle trade went to Deptford
- Largest number of cattle ever landed in one year was 224,831 (1897); of sheep, 783,440 (1882)
- Chicago meatpackers bypassed marketing system using a loophole in regulations by 1900
- Cattle boats from the Continent came up the Thames on Sundays and Wednesdays
- Market purchased three paddle steamers to convey more than 1.6 million animals to Deptford
- Animals were examined by a veterinary surgeon, suspects set aside for observation
- Hides, horns, fleeces, offal, manure, and litter were disinfected
- American cattle bore ear tags, and if one was found to be diseased, the American vet would telegraph the serial number to his government
- Quarantine rules minimized but could not prevent importation of contagious diseases
- Cattle plague (1877) and foot-and-mouth disease (1880 and 1882) had escaped from Deptford market
- George Philcox, a 28-year-old Southend station-master, was chosen as superintendent and was in charge for the next 40 years
- Employment conditions were investigated by social researcher Charles Booth
- Market had about 110 direct employees and 1500 casual workers, mostly drovers and slaughtermen, who were paid on piecework with irregular hours and precarious employment.

- George Philcox, a 28-year old Southend station-master, became superintendent of Deptford Foreign Cattle Market and remained in charge for 40 years until his death in 1912.
- The market had about 110 direct employees and 1500 casual workers, mostly drovers and slaughtermen, who were paid on piecework.
- Employment conditions were irregular and precarious due to dependence on ship arrivals and changing animal disease regulations.
- High-wage, insecure jobs attracted improvident men and resulted in much insobriety.
- Unemployment at the market could cause severe hardship in Deptford due to high migration for work.
- Drovers began as "ochre boys" marking animals for butchers and applied for a license from the City Corporation when old enough.
- Slaughtermen worked in gangs of four and earned high wages, but the work was brutalizing and conducive to drink.
- A carefully aimed blow with a poleaxe was the usual method of stunning animals, but it was not always effective.
- Women were employed to clean cattle and sheep intestines for sausage skins and condoms after men went on strike for more pay.
- The work was unpleasant and involved scraping off all fat and substance from the intestines.
- The stink from the work was described as insupportable.

- Cleaning cattle and sheep intestines for sausage skins and condoms was originally men's work, but in 1891, men went on strike for more pay and the job was assigned to women.
- Around 80-100 women and girls, aged 14 to 40, were employed daily and made 12s to 14s (£77 to £892018) a week.
- Queen Victoria took an interest in the working conditions of the girls at Deptford market, and her daughter-in-law, the Duchess of Albany, investigated.
- The Duchess of Albany found that the gut firms had been processing entrails from outside the market, posing a health risk. The City's markets committee banned the practice, leaving the women unemployed.
- A charity, the Deptford Fund, was started to support the unemployed women.
- Deptford market was a significant international livestock market, with roughly half of London's meat coming from the Foreign Cattle Market.
- The British were beef-hungry and had the money to buy meat in any market, making it the greatest market in the world.
- From Deptford market, a web of commercial relationships radiated out to livestock producers in distant parts of the planet.
- In the 1860s, the Dutch ports alone sent 150,000 cattle and 250,000 sheep to Britain, many of which passed through the markets of Austria and several German principalities before reaching their port of embarkation.
- Most European animals were shipped from Rotterdam and Hamburg, which were terminal stations of a great network of main German railway lines and branch lines that ran into Hungary, Poland, and Galicia and extended right up to the Bessarabian frontier.

- Most European animals were shipped from Rotterdam and Hamburg, but these towns were terminal stations of a vast German railway network that extended into Hungary, Poland, and Galicia, with many animals passing through Austrian and German markets before embarkation.
- In the 1860s, the Dutch ports sent 150,000 cattle and 250,000 sheep to Britain, with some shipments coming directly from Kronstadt, Russia, after being purchased in the Saint Petersburg cattle market.
- The Russian Empire was blacklisted for cattle plague in 1872, halting Russian cattle imports.
- The European livestock trade, except for Iceland, ended by the late 1880s due to disease endemic in export regions and lack of control by provincial authorities.
- The United States became the main supplier of livestock to Britain by 1878, with 3,144,400 American cattle landed at Deptford by the time it closed in 1913.
- American cattle exports to England began to address a surplus that could not be absorbed by local demand; when this changed by 1913, exports ceased.
- Early Western cattle, like Texas longhorns, were hardy but made tough eating; export-grade cattle were of higher quality, leading to upgrades in Western stock through Shorthorn and Hereford blood imports.
- The English export trade contributed to the demand for better American cattle, with the Hereford bull being a significant factor in increasing the size and quality of range cattle.
- By 1884, 95% of cattle exported came from the American West.
- In 1880, a 1,200-pound steer from the Western U.S. could be transported to Deptford market for £10-£12, including all costs, adding only 4d a pound to the carcase price.
- Rapid transatlantic cattle shipment became possible, with five cattle-laden steamers sailing from New York to England in one day.

- By 1884, 95% of cattle exported to England came from the American West.
- A round trip from Colorado, Wyoming, or Montana to Deptford market cost around £10 or £12, adding only 4d a pound to the carcase price of beef.
- In 1884, five cattle-laden steamers sailed from New York to England in one day, with cattle primarily from Ohio, Kentucky, Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Kansas, Nebraska, and Colorado.
- Some cattle exported to England came from as far away as Oregon, and the first consignment of western American cattle to take advantage of cheap transportation afforded by the Great Lakes arrived in Deptford in 1881.
- The exportation of cattle to England impacted the American livestock industry by promoting the growth of the Western packinghouse industry, expanding railway traffic, and improving the quality of American cattle.
- By 1884, it was estimated that one-sixth of all American herds were owned by Englishmen.
- Canadian range cattle, primarily from Alberta and Assiniboia, were exported to England via the Canadian Pacific Railway and the St. Lawrence River route.
- Exports of Canadian cattle to England rose from 115,000 in 1900 to 160,000 in 1905 but declined after a severe winter depleted half the range-cattle industry's working capital.
- Argentine cattle, formerly of inferior breed, became the greatest exporter in the world due to selective breeding and alfalfa forage.
- From about 1888, live cattle and sheep were shipped as deck cargo from Buenos Aires to London, taking about 30 days.

- Argentina:
	+ Supply of animals to Deptford came from Argentina
	+ Cattle were of inferior breed, used for hides, bones, and tallow
	+ Selective breeding and alfalfa forage improved the beef industry
	+ Live cattle and sheep shipped from Buenos Aires to London (30 days)
	+ Shorthorn bulls imported to improve herds
	+ Foot-and-mouth outbreak in 1900 led to closure of trade
	+ Chilled Argentine beef became a better alternative
	+ Severe unemployment in Deptford

- Australia and New Zealand:
	+ Cattle and sheep shipped to Deptford Market from Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, and Dunedin
	+ First commercial shipment from Sydney in 1894, but sold at a loss
	+ More successful voyages in 1895, but later shipments had "terrible" losses
	+ Angers shipment of 381 cattle from Gladstone, Queensland, led to prohibition of the ship from carrying live stock for a year
	+ 607 cattle and 57 sheep lost out of 2,654 and 3,882 shipped, respectively

- The Beef Trust:
	+ Cartel of large Chicago meat packers controlling market shares and fixing meat prices in the US
	+ By 1900, controlled shipping of live cattle to England from America
	+ Allegedly bought up shops in Smithfield Market, fixed British beef prices, controlled lairages at Deptford Market, and sent meat directly to Smithfield
	+ Winston Churchill set up an inquiry in 1909, which confirmed most allegations but found that the Trust could not fix the price of beef in the UK due to declining exports and increasing Argentine refrigerated beef shipments

- Animal welfare:
	+ Concerns about animal welfare during long journeys
	+ Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals took up the issue after Angers shipment

- Cattle were sent from various grassland regions to Deptford market for slaughter, with long journeys causing stress and injury to the animals.
- In the early 1900s, a meat trade trust controlled the North Atlantic meat trade, but couldn't fix the price of beef due to American beef export decline and Argentine refrigerated beef imports.
- In 1909, an inquiry was set up by Winston Churchill, President of the Board of Trade, to investigate the control and effect of meat supply, distribution, and price by any combination of firms or companies, following allegations by C.W. Bowerman, Labour MP for Deptford.
- Transatlantic cattle ship conditions were poor, especially in early days, with tramp steamers being the worst culprits. High freights led to temporary decks and overcrowding, increasing risks during winter.
- In 1879, the British government's chief veterinary officer reported on animals jettisoned or dying from injury or suffocation, with 10,667 animals thrown overboard, 1,210 landed dead, and 718 slaughtered on landing.
- Samuel Plimsoll campaigned against the transatlantic cattle trade in 1890, citing its danger to ships in stormy weather, cruelty to animals, and lack of necessity.
- Cattle ships were unstable if animals were carried on the upper deck or on temporary platforms, causing animals to be washed overboard or jettisoned to save the vessel.
- If animals were carried in the holds, they could stifle to death after hatches were battened down in bad weather, leading captains to take risks in leaving the hatches open.

- Cattle ship "Erin" sailed from New York to London in Dec. 1889 with 527 cattle and 74 men, never heard from again
- Cattle ships were unstable, cruel to animals, and unnecessary
- Ships were unstable if cattle were carried on upper deck or temporary platforms, obstructing crew duties
- Animals could be washed overboard or deliberately jettisoned, or die from stifling in holds
- Captains took risks in leaving hatches open, leading to animals standing in their own dung and falling/getting injured
- Cattle attendants not allowed to euthanize injured livestock due to insurance companies' refusal (probably untrue)
- Cattle attendants used cruel methods to make animals stand, such as piercing with pitchforks, twisting tails, beating heads, pouring paraffin in ears
- Cattle attendants were "cowboys of the seas" and "stiffs"
- Government inquiry confirmed many of Plimsoll's allegations, leading to regulations prohibiting worst practices
- Export trade dominated by four American meat packers: Swift, Armour, Hammond, Morris
- Liner system essential for close coordination, regularity, and long-term contractual relationships
- By 1892, North Atlantic animal losses reduced to less than 1%, but dung and urine still accumulated in holds and caused unbearable ammoniacal stench
- Cattle on deck had seawater freeze on their backs, causing broken legs
- Cattle taken to market by train, mostly to Chicago, then railed to ports on eastern seaboard for shipment to England
- Cattle not supposed to travel more than 28 hours at a time according to U.S. law.

* Cattle transported on ships from New York to the Thames often had seawater frozen on their backs and experienced broken legs due to rough sea conditions.
* The journey took an average of 11 days, and cattle could smell land and begin bellowing when they were 30-40 hours away from shore.
* In the United States, cattle were transported by train to Chicago, where there was a special market for "export grade" cattle that were then shipped to England.
* In Canada, cattle were taken by train to Montreal from the foothills of the Rocky Mountains.
* According to a U.S. federal law of 1873, animals were not supposed to travel more than 28 hours at a time without being unloaded for water, food, and rest. However, this law was often ignored and animals were sometimes left on the train for up to 100 hours at a time.
* Water and food were not always provided during these long journeys, and animals were often overcrowded to save on freight charges.
* Cattle attendants used a tool called a cattle prod to make animals that had fallen down stand up again to avoid them being trampled.
* A government official noted that many cattle arrived at their destination crippled or dead due to the harsh conditions of transportation.
* Samuel Plimsoll argued that the transatlantic cattle trade had no rational commercial purpose and only served to enrich dishonest traders.

- The present system of transporting cattle for export in Canada results in many injured and dead animals due to long rail journeys.
- The Canadian Live Stock Commissioner criticized the live cattle trade as wasteful, unbusinesslike, and unprofitable for producers.
- Samuel Plimsoll argued that the transatlantic cattle trade only benefits dishonest traders, as they can misrepresent live cattle as "best Scotch", "town-killed", or "English-fed" beef for higher profits.
- An alternative to live cattle trade is American chilled meat, which was commercially successful in London before the Foreign Cattle Market became popular.
- Chilled meat is cheaper and more efficient to transport than live cattle, and it is difficult for butchers to distinguish between British and American meat if imported dead.
- At Smithfield Market, Deptford-killed American beef sells for 10-15% more than American chilled beef, possibly due to fraudulent reselling as Scotch or English beef.
- The British farming industry accused butchers of cheating, while butchers claimed that customers were not concerned about the origin of the meat.
- Plimsoll argued that chilled meat is as good as, if not better than, Deptford-killed beef due to the chilling process, which is equivalent to well-hung meat.
- Victorian and Edwardian consumers' opinions on chilled beef are unclear, with some preferring British-grown beef due to prejudice and snobbery.
- Richard Perren of Aberdeen University argued that the live meat trade survived because the chilled meat trade was riskier, as it had to be sold promptly upon arrival at the London docks.
- However, Perren also acknowledged that chilled meat could keep for an additional 14 days with cold-storage, and that the live animal trade was also risky.

Notes:

* Current Canadian cattle transport system results in injured and dead animals
* Criticism of live cattle trade as wasteful and unprofitable
* Plimsoll's argument against live cattle trade for enriching dishonest traders
* American chilled meat as an alternative
* Difficulty in distinguishing between British and American meat if imported dead
* Price premium for Deptford-killed American beef over American chilled beef
* Accusations of

- Plimsoll argued that customers should be able to choose British-grown beef if they are willing to pay more
- Richard Perren of Aberdeen University argued that the live meat trade survived because the chilled meat trade was riskier
- Live beasts did not have to be sold as quickly as chilled meat, which had to be sold promptly upon arrival at the London docks
- However, Perren acknowledged that livestock had to be slaughtered within 10 days of arrival and that the live animal trade was also risky
- Some butchers fraudulently sold Deptford-killed meat as English, with the price being higher
- Effective compulsory marking of origin was not introduced until 1933, and no prosecutions were attempted
- In the Victorian era, foreign merino sheep were slaughtered at Deptford, sent to Cardiff, and sold as Welsh mutton
- Scientific American reported in 1904 that it was hard to tell the difference between live American cattle and English cattle
- A writer for a Chicago livestock magazine in 1912 could not find any American meat for sale at Smithfield
- An English port medical officer noted a disparity between port-killed wholesale prices and butchers' retail prices
- The transatlantic cattle trade made for cheaper bread by allowing American grain to be used as ballast in vessels laden with cattle
- The Foreign Cattle Market went into a decline due to an embargo on Argentine cattle and diminishing American and Canadian supplies
- The site of the Foreign Cattle Market became a supply base for the troops in France during World War I and was later sold to the government
- Some remains of the old Market and former dockyard, such as boundary walls, still stand today

Sources:

- Alsford, Niki J.P. (2021). "The City within the City: A Glimpse of Elite Formation in Deptford, London and Dadaocheng, Taipei"
- Baxter, Arthur (1896). "Butchers and fishmongers". In Booth, Charles (ed.). Life and Labour of the People in London. London and New York: Macmillan.

- The site of Deptford's old market and former dockyard, known as Convoys Wharf, was used as a supply base during a war and later sold to the government.
- Some remains of the old Market, such as boundary walls, still stand and are listed buildings.
- In the late 1800s, Argentina's animal industry, including cattle and alfalfa production, was studied by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
- In the 1860s, a cattle-plague outbreak occurred in Britain, leading to the Contagious Diseases (Animals) Act in 1869.
- In the late 1800s, reports on contagious and infectious diseases in animals were published in the Journal of the Royal Agricultural Society of England.
- In the 1870s, the Veterinary Department of the Privy Council Office published annual reports on animal diseases.
- In the 1890s, the Transatlantic Cattle Trade and its regulations were discussed in The Journal of Comparative Medicine and Veterinary Surgery and Archives.
- In the early 1900s, a Departmental Committee Report on the meat-packing industry was published by the Federal Trade Commission.
- Charles Booth's notebooks and studies from the late 1800s and early 1900s provide information on butchers and fishmongers in London.
- In the early 1900s, ocean steamships were discussed in a book by Forrest Capie and Richard Perren.

* "Annual Report of the Veterinary Department of the Privy Council Office for the Year 1878 with an Appendix" (1879) - Discusses the state of the livestock industry in Britain in 1878.
* Bryden, Williamson (1891) - Describes the transatlantic cattle trade and its regulations from a veterinary perspective.
* Capie, Forrest; Perren, Richard (1980) - Examines the British market for meat from 1850-1914.
* Chadwick, F.E.; et al. (1891) - Discusses ocean steamships and their role in the livestock industry.
* Clemen, Rudolph Alexander (1923) - Provides an overview of the American livestock and meat industry.
* Cotton, James Sutherland, ed. (1896) - Contains the text of the Diseases of Animals Act, 1896.
* Critchell, James Troubridge; Raymond, Joseph (1912) - Provides a history of the frozen meat trade.
* Davies, W.H. (1908) - Describes the experiences of a "super-tramp" who traveled the country and encountered various aspects of the livestock industry.
* "Deptford Live-Stock Reports" (1909) - Provides reports on the state of livestock in Deptford.
* Dickens, Charles (1867) - Discusses the importance of the livestock industry to the nation.
* Edwards-Callaway, Lily N.; Calvo-Lorenzo, Michelle S. (2020) - Examines animal welfare in the U.S. slaughter industry, with a focus on fed cattle.
* Evans, Simon M. (1979) - Discusses the importation of Canadian beef to Victorian Britain.
* Evans, Simon M. (1983) - Examines the origins of ranching in western Canada.
* Evans, Stewart P.; Skinner, Keith (2001) - Provides a sourcebook on Jack the Ripper, which may include information on the livestock industry.
* Fisher,

- "The World's Greatest Meat Market" (20 March 1912) in Breeder's Gazette, Vol. LXI, no. 12, discussing the Chicago meat market.

 	+ Discusses the range-cattle industry in the 19th century.

 	+ Describes contagious pleuro-pneumonia in domesticated animals.

- Perren, Richard (2017). Taste, Trade and Technology: the Development of the International Meat Industry Since 1840. Discusses the development of the international meat industry since 1840.
- Perry, Edward E. (1885). "Live Stock and Meat Traffic of Chicago". Annual Report of the Bureau of Animal Industry for the Year 1884. Covers the live stock and meat traffic of Chicago in 1884.
